translated: The idea is that a turn is based on differences.

analyzed: atha ityādinā vyācaṣṭe
translated: Beginning with athêtyādi, he explains.

original: sarveṣāṃ bhedānāṃ sarvatra kārye paryāyeṇa krameṇa upayogāt /
analyzed: sarveṣām bhedānām sarvatra kārye paryāyeṇa krameṇa upayogāt
translated: Because all differences are useful in every effect by turns, in sequence.

analyzed: etat ca yadā pradhāna śakt
translated: And this is when the power of the principal...

original: pradhānaśaktir eva vastu satī saivārthakriyāyām upayujyate /
analyzed: eva
translated: The power of the principal itself, being real, is itself useful in effective action.

original: bhedāḥ kevalaṃ vyavasthāmātrahetuvaḥ paramārthatas tv asanta eva /
analyzed: bhedāḥ kevalam paramārthataḥ tu asantaḥ eva
translated: The differences are merely the cause of the establishment, but in reality they do not exist at all.

analyzed: tadā idam ucyate
translated: This is said:

analyzed: śakteḥ vā ityādi
translated: Of the power and so on.

original: traiguṇyalakṣaṇāyāḥ tanniveśinyāḥ pūrvam akārakābhimatapadārthaniveśinyāḥ paścād rūpāntareṇa kārakābhimatarūpeṇa vipariṇatayā ///
analyzed: traiguṇya lakṣaṇāyāḥ tad niveśinyāḥ pūrvam akāraka abhimata padārtha niveśinyāḥ paścāt rūpa antareṇa kāraka abhimata rūpeṇa vipariṇatayā
translated: Of the power characterized by the three qualities, which is included in it, which includes the previously intended non-agent objects, which later transforms into a different form, into the form intended as an agent...

original: yasya sat tathoktaḥ ekasya / / / / sya kathaṃ naiva /
translated: How is it not at all of the one thus spoken of?

original: etena sa kiṃ tasyaiva vastuna ity etad vivṛtaṃ /
analyzed: etena sa kim tasya eva vastunaḥ iti etat vivṛtam
translated: By this, what was said as is that of that very thing? is explained.

analyzed: śakteḥ vā iti yat uktam
translated: As for what was said about power,

analyzed: tatra āha vipariṇāmaḥ vā iti
translated: there he says transformation and so on.

original: pūrvasmād avasthābhedād avyatirekiṇyāḥ śākteḥ parimāṇo 'vasthāntaraprāptir vā kathaṃ //
analyzed: pūrvasmāt avasthā bhedāt a vyatirekiṇyāḥ śākteḥ parimāṇaḥ vasthā antara prāptiḥ vā katham
translated: How can there be the attainment of a different state of power which is not different from the previous state?

original: atheṣyate pūrvāvasthāyāḥ paścād viśeṣaḥ traiguṇyasya tato viśeṣe vā / / / / ci / / / / /u / / ///
analyzed: atha iṣyate pūrva avasthāyāḥ paścāt viśeṣaḥ traiguṇyasya tatas viśeṣe
translated: Or if it is accepted that there is a difference later from the previous state, then there would be a difference in the three qualities.

original: eṣyate / bhedasāmānyayoś ca paraspar / da evaṃ ca sati tadvati sāmānyaviśeṣavati vastuni atyantaṃ bhedābhedau syātāṃ /🔽viśeṣebhyaḥ sāmānyasyāvyatirekāt bhinnaṃ rūpam ity antabhedaḥ sāmānyasyābhāvāt /
analyzed: viśeṣebhyaḥ sāmānyasya avyatirekāt bhinnam rūpam iti anta bhedaḥ sāmānyasya abhāvāt
translated: If it is accepted, and if there is mutual difference between difference and generality, and if it is so, then in the thing which has that, which has generality and particularity, there would be absolute difference and non-difference.🔽Because the generality is not different from the particularities, there is the extreme difference that it is a different form. Because of the absence of generality,

original: sāmānyād viśeṣāṇām avyatirekād aikyam ity antābhedaḥ /
analyzed: sāmānyāt viśeṣāṇām avyatirekāt aikyam iti anta abhedaḥ
translated: because the particularities are not different from the generality, there is the extreme non-difference that they are one.

analyzed: sarvathā viśeṣāṇām abhāvāt  ekam bhedasāmā
translated: In every way, because of the absence of particularities,🔽one has the difference and generality...

original: sadṛśāsadṛśātmanoḥ sāmānyaviśeṣayo / / / / vāś ced bhedina iti saṃbandhaḥ /
translated: If the different ones are of the nature of the similar and dissimilar, there is the relation of generality and particularity.

original: abhinnenātmanā pradhānākhyena teṣām eva bhedānāṃ sātmabhūtena tadvantaḥ /
analyzed: abhinnena ātmanā pradhāna ākhyena teṣām eva bhedānām sātma bhūtena tadvantaḥ
translated: By the undifferentiated self called Prakriti, they are possessed of that as their self.

original: syur abhinnasvabhāvavantaḥ syuḥ //🔽abhinnaḥ svabhāvaḥ pradhānākhya ātmā rūpaṃ yasya bhedasya sa tadabhinnasvabhāvātmā tadbhāvas tasmād bhedasyāpi kutaḥ /
analyzed: syuḥ abhinna svabhāvavantaḥ syuḥ  abhinnaḥ svabhāvaḥ pradhāna ākhyaḥ ātmā rūpam yasya bhedasya sa tad abhinna svabhāva ātmā tad bhāvaḥ tasmāt bhedasya api kutas
translated: They would have an undifferentiated nature.

analyzed: parasparam bhedaḥ na eva anenā
translated: How can there be difference among them? How can there be mutual difference among the modifications, by the undifferentiated nature called Prakriti, which is their self, which has that as its undifferentiated nature, and which has that as its nature?🔽By this, they do not have a self.

analyzed: ātmā na bhavati dasya aneka ātmaka tvāt
translated: Because it has many selves.

analyzed: api
translated: By that self, by that difference, by that universal object also.

original: tatheti sāmānyātmanā bhavituṃ na yuktaṃ bhedād avyatiriktatvāt sāmānyasya samānatā nāstīty arthaḥ /
analyzed: tathā iti sāmānya ātmanā bhavitum na yuktam bhedāt a vyatirikta tvāt sāmānyasya samāna tā na asti iti arthaḥ
translated: Thus, it is not proper to exist by the nature of the universal, because the universal is not separate from the difference. The meaning is that there is no sameness.

analyzed: etena atyanta bhedaḥ vyākhyātaḥ tathābhāve hi iti
translated: By this, absolute difference is explained. For if it existed thus,

original: sāmānyātmakatve pradhānasyeṣyamāṇe pradhānātmātaddharmā bhedadharmā na syāt /🔽avya ///
analyzed: sāmānya ātmaka tve pradhānasya iṣyamāṇe pradhāna ātmā a tad dharmā bheda dharmā na syāt  avya
translated: if the universal nature of Prakriti were accepted, the modifications would not have the nature of Prakriti and its qualities.🔽They would not have the nature of the universal.

analyzed: na syāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that they would not have the nature of the universal.

original: avasthātadvatoḥ parasparaṃ bhedaḥ syād iti yāvat /
analyzed: avasthā tadvatoḥ parasparam bhedaḥ syāt iti yāvat
translated: The difference between the state and its possessor would be mutual, that is the extent of it.

analyzed: tam eva sādhayan āha
translated: Establishing that very [difference], he says:

analyzed: na hi ayam ityādi
translated: For this [universal] is not seen to be different from the modifications.

analyzed: ayam eka svabhāvaḥ
translated: This is of one nature.

analyzed: pravṛtti nivṛttimān na yuktaḥ iti saṃbandhaḥ
translated: It is not proper to have both engagement and disengagement, this is the connection.

analyzed: sthānam pravṛttiḥ
translated: Abiding is engagement.

analyzed: vigamaḥ nivṛttiḥ
translated: Separation is disengagement.

original: tathā hi sthitāyāṃ śaktau avasthānāṃ nivṛttir iṣyate /
analyzed: tathā hi sthitāyām śaktau avasthānām nivṛttiḥ iṣyate
translated: For thus, when the power is abiding, the states are considered to be disengaged.

original: etenānyonyaṃ vā tayor bheda ityādi vyākhyātam /
analyzed: etena anyonyam vā tayoḥ bhedaḥ ityādi vyākhyātam
translated: By this, the explanation of or their difference from each other and so on is given.

analyzed: na ityādinā para abhiprāyam āśaṃkate
translated: With No and so on, he suspects the opponent's intention.

original: kiṃtu tayor api bhedasāmānyayor bhedo bhaved yadi /
analyzed: tu   api     bhavet
translated: But if there were a difference of those two, difference and generality,

original: kvacid bhede sāmānye vā asya sāṃkhyasya bhedo 'bhedo vā aikāntiko na hīti saṃbandhaḥ /
analyzed: kvacid bhede sāmānye vā asya sāṃkhyasya bhedaḥ bhedaḥ vā aikāntikaḥ na hi iti saṃbandhaḥ
translated: in some difference or generality, this Sāṃkhya would have an absolute difference or non-difference, this is the connection.

original: ekatvavāditvāt parasya bheda aikāntiko nāstīti gamyata evābhedas tu katham aikāntiko nety atra kāraṇam āha /
analyzed: ekatva vādi tvāt parasya bhedaḥ aikāntikaḥ nā asti iti gamyate eva abhedaḥ tu katham aikāntikaḥ nā iti atra kāraṇam āha
translated: Since the opponent is a proponent of oneness, it is understood that there is no absolute difference, but how is non-difference not absolute? Here he gives the reason:

analyzed: vivekena ityādi
translated: By discrimination and so on.

original: sāmānyaṃ śaktiḥ vyaktayo viśeṣā ity evaṃ bhedena vyavasthānāt /🔽yenetyādy ā / / / / ///
analyzed: sāmānyam śaktiḥ vyaktayaḥ viśeṣāḥ iti evam bhedena vyavasthānāt 🔽yena ityādi ā
translated: Since generality is power and the particulars are the specificities, thus there is establishment by difference.🔽By which and so on is the explanation of the opponent's intention.

original: sāmānyam ity etad yenātmanā vyavasthāpyate yadi / / / / tmanā sāmānyaviśeṣayor bhedās tadā bheda evātyantaṃ yadītyādinā vyācaṣṭe
translated: If the common nature by which the distinction of the general and particular is established is by that very nature, then there is absolute difference. He explains this with if and so on.

analyzed: yam ātmānam iti śakti vyakti ātmakam
translated: That nature means the nature consisting of power and manifestation.

original: tenātmanā sāmānyaviśeṣayor yadi bheda iti saṃbandhaḥ /
analyzed: tena ātmanā sāmānya viśeṣayoḥ yadi bhedaḥ iti saṃbandhaḥ
translated: The connection is: if the general and particular have a difference by that nature.

original: etad eva sphuṭayann āha yasmād ityādi /
analyzed: etat eva sphuṭayan āha yasmāt ityādi
translated: To make this clear, he says because and so on.

original: tau hi bhedavyasthāpakāv ātmānau tayor iti sāmāny / ///
analyzed: tau hi ātmānau tayoḥ iti sāmāni
translated: For those two natures are the establishers of the distinction. Of those two means of the general and particular.

original: bhūtau tau ced vyatirekiṇau parasparabhinnau tadā vyatireka e bheda eva /
analyzed: bhūtau tau ced vyatirekiṇau paraspara bhinnau tadā vyatirekaḥ bhedaḥ eva
translated: If those two natures are different, separate from each other, then there is absolute difference, that is, absolute distinction.

analyzed: kim kāraṇam svabhāva bhedāt
translated: What is the reason? Because of the difference in nature.

original: syāt matam avasthāvasthātror bhedavyavasthāpako bhāva eva bhidyate na svabhāva ity āha /
analyzed: syāt matam avasthā avasthātroḥ bheda vyavasthāpakaḥ bhāvaḥ eva bhidyate na svabhāvaḥ iti āha
translated: It may be thought that the very entity that establishes the distinction between the states is different, not the nature. He says:

analyzed: svabhāvaḥ hi ityādi
translated: For nature and so on.

original: svabhāva eva bhāva ity arthaḥ /🔽tathā ceti bhedasāmānyayor iti sāmānyaviśeṣayoḥ svātmanau svabhāvabhūtau tau ced vyatirekiṇau paraspa ///
analyzed: svabhāvaḥ eva bhāvaḥ iti arthaḥ  tathā ca iti bheda sāmānyayoḥ iti sāmānya viśeṣayoḥ sva ātmanau svabhāva bhūtau tau ced vyatirekiṇau
translated: The meaning is that nature itself is the entity.

analyzed: bhedaḥ eva kim kāraṇam svabhāva bhedāt
translated: And if those two natures, which are the natures of the general and particular, are different, separate from each other, then there is absolute difference. What is the reason? Because of the difference in nature.

original: syāt matam avasthātror bhedavyavasthāpako bhāva eva bhidyate na svabhāva ity āha r atyantabhede sati bhedasya niḥsāmānyatā sāmānyasya nirviśeṣatā
analyzed: syāt matam avasthātroḥ bheda vyavasthāpakaḥ bhāvaḥ eva bhidyate na svabhāvaḥ iti āha r atyanta bhede sati bhedasya niḥsāmānya tā sāmānyasya nirviśeṣa tā
translated: It might be argued that it is the entity itself that becomes differentiated, and not the nature, which serves to differentiate the two states. To this he says: If there were absolute difference, then there would be no commonality in difference, and no particularity in the universal.

analyzed: syāt iti saṃbandhaḥ
translated: The word 'syāt' (would be) is to be connected.

original: sāmānyasya bhedavatvaṃ bhedānāṃ ca sāmānyavatvaṃ na syād asaṃbhavād iti yāvat /
analyzed: sāmānyasya bhedava tvam bhedānām ca sāmānyava tvam na syāt asaṃbhavāt iti yāvat
translated: There would be no commonality in difference, and no particularity in the universal, because it is impossible.

original: yadvadghaṭādīnāṃ bhedānāṃ saṃbandhābhāvāt parasparaṃ tadvattā nāsti / / ///
analyzed: yadvat ghaṭa ādīnām bhedānām saṃbandha abhāvāt parasparam tadvat tā na asti
translated: Just as there is no mutual presence of pot etc. due to the absence of relation between the differences.

original: nakatvena saṃbandhābhāvāt uktam iti na syāt sāmānyabhedadhīr ity atrāntare /
translated: The statement 'there would be no cognition of the universal and the difference' is made here, because there is no relation as non-existence.

original: atha vā asthāne 'yaṃ yatnaḥ kriyate paraiḥ /
analyzed: atha vai asthāne yam yatnaḥ kriyate paraiḥ
translated: Or else, this effort is made by others in the wrong place.

analyzed: kalpitam sāmānyam sva lakṣaṇāt bhinnam
translated: The imagined universal is different from the particular.

original: kiṃ vā neti tad dhi nityam iṣyate /
analyzed: kim vā na iti tat hi nityam iṣyate
translated: Or is it not? For that is considered to be eternal.

analyzed: paraiḥ tatas ca anartha kriyā kāri tvāt śaśaviṣāṇa prakhyam
translated: And because it does not perform any function, it is like a rabbit's horn.

analyzed: tatra artha kriyā arthinaḥ
translated: There, those who seek to accomplish a purpose think about difference and non-difference.

original: m anyatra yathā parikalpitāyā vyāvṛ / / ty etad darśayitum āhāpi cetyādi /
analyzed: anyatra yathā parikalpitāyāḥ iti etat darśayitum āha api ca ityādi
translated: In other cases, in order to show this, he says 'and also' etc.

original: yam ātmānam arthakriyāyogyaṃ puraskṛtyālaṃbanīkṛtya tatsādhyaphalavāñchāvān tenātmanā yatsādhyaṃ phalaṃ tadabhilāṣavān /
analyzed: yam ātmānam arthakriyā yogyam puraskṛtya ālaṃbanīkṛtya tad sādhya phala vāñchāvān tena ātmanā yat sādhyam phalam tad abhilāṣavān
translated: The person who, placing the self which is fit for effective action in front, making it the object, who desires the fruit to be accomplished by that, who desires the fruit to be accomplished by that self,

analyzed: ayam puruṣaḥ pravartate
translated: this person acts.

original: tadāśrayau tadadhiṣṭhānau bhedābhedau cintyete /🔽tasya cārthakriyāyogyasya svā / / ///
analyzed: tad āśrayau tad adhiṣṭhānau bheda abhedau cintyete  tasya ca artha kriyā yogyasya svā
translated: The difference and non-difference based on that are to be considered.🔽And of that which is fit for effective action, the similarity with the appearance in the limited cognition,

original: lpabuddhipratibhāsānurodhinyā kṛtavya / / / / / / samānatā asty evādhyavasitatadbhāvā iyataivārthakriyārthino bhedābhedacintā /
translated: is indeed real. The mere fact that the seeker of effective action determines that nature, this much is enough for the consideration of difference and non-difference.

analyzed: samāptā tatas narthakriyā kāriṇaḥ sāmānyasya kim sva lakṣaṇena
translated: Therefore, what is the use of the universal which does not perform effective action, with the particular?

analyzed: bheda abheda cintayā iti
translated: The consideration of difference and non-difference.

original: vastv eva sāmānyam astu kiṃ parikalpitayā vyāvṛtyety āha /
analyzed: vastu eva sāmānyam astu kim parikalpitayā vyāvṛtyā iti āha
translated: Let the thing itself be the universal. What is the use of the imagined exclusion? He says:

analyzed: vastu na anveti iti sva lakṣaṇānām parasparam
translated: The thing does not follow. The particulars do not mutually...

analyzed: R ta tat āha pravṛti ādi ityādi
translated: Therefore, he says by activity and so on.

analyzed: ādi śabdāt tulya utpatti nirodha ādi prasaṃgataḥ
translated: By the word and so on, the absurdity of having the same origin and cessation follows.

analyzed: sarve eva ityādinā vyācaṣṭe
translated: He explains with all and so on.

analyzed: viśeṣam eva artha kriyā yogyam
translated: Only the particular is fit for effective action.

analyzed: svabhāva ākhyam ātma bhūtam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: having as its own nature the self.

analyzed: kasya bhāvasya vastunaḥ dhikṛtya pravartate
translated: With reference to which entity, which thing, does it operate?

original: sa eva hīty arthakriyākārī viśeṣaḥ /🔽tatheti gaur ityādiśabdaiḥ arthakriyārthī hi svalakṣa ///
analyzed: saḥ eva hi iti arthakriyā kārī viśeṣaḥ  tathā iti gauḥ ityādi śabdaiḥ arthakriyā arthī hi
translated: The meaning is: that very particular which performs a function.
Thus, one who desires to perform a function, by words such as 'cow', etc., determines the specific particular itself, due to the power of his own ascertainment.

analyzed: śabda vyāpāra apekṣayā etat uktam
translated: This is said with reference to the operation of words.

original: śābde tu jñāne svalakṣaṇapratibhāso nāstīti svalakṣaṇam avācyam uktam ity avirodhaḥ /
analyzed: śābde tu jñāne sva lakṣaṇa pratibhāsaḥ na asti iti sva lakṣaṇam avācyam uktam iti avirodhaḥ
translated: But in verbal cognition, the specific particular does not appear, therefore it is said that the specific particular is inexpressible. Thus there is no contradiction.

original: dravyatvādayas tu tatreti gaur ityādiśabdair gavādicodanāyāṃ /
analyzed: dravya tva ādayaḥ tu tatra iti gauḥ iti ādi śabdaiḥ go ādi codanāyām
translated: But the universals such as substance, etc. are there, in that case, when cows, etc. are denoted by words such as 'cow', etc.

original: kasmād yathāsvaṃ dravyatvādiśabdais teṣāṃ dravyāt pṛthagabhidhān / ///
analyzed: kasmāt yathāsvam dravya tva ādi śabdaiḥ teṣām dravyāt pṛthak abhidhān
translated: Why are they not denoted separately from substances by words such as 'substance', etc., according to their own nature?
Commentary on the Discussion of Means of Knowledge

original: tyādi / arthasya gavādes tena gotvādinā sāmānyenāvyabhicārāt /
analyzed: R arthasya go ādeḥ tena go tva ādinā sāmānyena avyabhicārāt
translated: Because the meaning, such as a cow, is not deviated from by that universal such as cowness.

original: tato 'rthād gatiḥ sāmānyānāṃ syān na tu viśeṣaśabdaḥ sāmānye vyāpriyate nirloṭhitaṃ caitad ācāryadiṅnāgena sāmānyaparīkṣādau yathā viśeṣaśabdānāṃ
analyzed: tatas rthāt gatiḥ sāmānyānām syāt na tu viśeṣa śabdaḥ sāmānye vyāpriyate nirloṭhitam ca etat ācārya diṅnāgena sāmānya parīkṣā ādau yathā viśeṣa śabdānām
translated: the specific words

analyzed: na sāmānye vṛttiḥ iti
translated: do not operate on the universal.

analyzed: atra codyate
translated: And here it is objected: The universal is...

analyzed: tat api d eva
translated: That too is so.

original: tathā vikalpabuddhipratibhāsasya na bāhyena dravyeṇāvyabhicārā sti tasya svatantratvāt /
analyzed: tathā vikalpa buddhi pratibhāsasya na bāhyena dravyeṇa avyabhicārā sti tasya svatantra tvāt
translated: Similarly, there is no invariable concomitance of the appearance in the conceptual cognition with the external substance, because that [appearance] is independent.

original: ucyate svalakṣaṇam eva sajātīyavyāvṛttaṃ viśeṣas tad eva vijātīyavyāvṛttim apekṣyābhedenopāttaṃ sāmānyam ity ucyate /
analyzed: ucyate sva lakṣaṇam eva sajātīya vyāvṛttam viśeṣaḥ tat eva vijātīya vyāvṛttim apekṣya abhedena upāttam sāmānyam iti ucyate
translated: It is said that the specific particular itself, distinguished from the homogeneous, is the specific [particular]. That very [specific particular], when taken as undifferentiated in relation to the distinction from the heterogeneous, is called the universal.

analyzed: tatas sāmānya viśeṣayoḥ vastutas eka tvāt kṛ
translated: Therefore, since the universal and the specific particular are in reality one, the specific particular is the basis of the conceptual cognition.

original: bhedāt tu kevalaṃ kvacic chābdī pratipatti /
analyzed: tu
translated: But due to the difference, the understanding is verbal in some cases,

analyzed: kvacid ārthī iti ucyate
translated: and in some cases it is said to be real.

analyzed: tat iti tasmāt ayam puruṣaḥ
translated: That means: Therefore, this person,

analyzed: go ādi pratyupasthāpitam go ādi śabda saṃnipātitam arthakriyā āśrayam
translated: is presented by the word cow, etc., and is the basis of effective action, which is brought together by the word cow, etc.

analyzed: artha antarasya sāmānyasya upanyāsena
translated: by introducing a separate universal.

original: bhedasāmānyākāratayā dvimukhā buddhir yasya sa tathoktaḥ /
analyzed: bheda sāmānya ākāra tayā dvimukhā buddhiḥ yasya sa tathā uktaḥ
translated: He who has an understanding with two aspects, the general and the particular, is so described.

original: yo 'sya gavāder ātmā svabhāvaḥ ananyabhāgasādhāraṇaḥ ///🔽yam arthaṃ / / / / / / mantaṃ puraskṛtyety ālaṃba /
analyzed: yaḥ sya gavādeḥ ātmā svabhāvaḥ ananya bhāga sādhāraṇaḥ  yam artham    puraskṛtya iti ālaṃba
translated: That which is the self, the nature, of this cow etc., which is not shared by anything else, is the universal.🔽The object which is...🔽... having placed it in front, is the meaning of the compound.

analyzed: kṛtya viśiṣṭa artha kriyā arthī tām eva āha yathā ityādi
translated: He states the same with just as and so on.

original: yathā gor vāhadohādāv arthī gām eva puraskṛtya pravartate /
analyzed: yathā goḥ vāha doha ādau arthī gām eva puraskṛtya pravartate
translated: Just as one who desires plowing and milking from a cow engages in it having placed the cow itself in front.

original: anyasaṃbhavina iti gor anyasminn aśve saṃbhavino 'rthasyārthī gāṃ puraskṛtya na pravartata iti vākyārthaḥ /
analyzed: anya saṃbhavinaḥ iti goḥ anyasmin aśve saṃbhavinaḥ rthasya arthī gām puraskṛtya na pravartate iti vākya arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of the sentence is: one who desires an object that is possible for something other than a cow, not engaging in it having placed a cow in front, because it is possible for a horse which is other than a cow.

analyzed: samarthanīyaḥ kaḥ rthaḥ nyasaṃbhavi iti āha
translated: What is the object to be established that is possible for something else? He says:🔽Just as in the case of a battle...

analyzed: yathā yuddha vesa iti
translated: ... is stated.

original: ṃ / / ditam iti / / / / pariṇāmena sa / / / / / / /c / danayā gavādīnāṃ bhedā / / gavādiśabdaiś codanayā tadety arthaḥ /
analyzed: iti   pariṇāmena go ādīnām bhedāḥ go ādi śabdaiḥ codanayā tadā iti arthaḥ
translated: ... by the transformation of the substance etc. into the universal, by the transformation of the case endings. The meaning is: by the injunction of the words cow etc., which are the transformation of the substance etc. into the universal, by the transformation of the case endings.

original: kriyārthinaḥ pravṛttikāle prāptum anabhipretatvāt dravyādisāmānyasyeti vibhaktivipariṇāmena saṃbandhaḥ /
analyzed: kriyā arthinaḥ pravṛtti kāle prāptum anabhipreta tvāt dravya ādi sāmānyasya iti vibhakti vipariṇāmena saṃbandhaḥ
translated: Because the general substance etc. is not intended to be obtained at the time of engagement for one who desires action.

original: satyaṃ gavādayo viśeṣāś codyante 'rthakriyārthibhis te tu bhedā dravya
analyzed: satyam gavā ādayaḥ viśeṣāḥ codyante rtha kriyā arthibhiḥ te tu bhedāḥ dravya
translated: The particular cows and so on are indeed enjoined by those who seek to accomplish a purpose, but they are differences of substance.
Therefore he says:

analyzed: gavādi samāveśāt iti
translated: Because of the inclusion of cows and so on.

original: avyatirekavādinaḥ sāṃkhyasya gavādiṣu bhedeṣu sāmānyatāṃ samāveśāt tādātmyenānupraveśād gavādisvabhāvatvād iti yāvat /
analyzed: avyatireka vādinaḥ sāṃkhyasya gavā ādiṣu bhedeṣu sāmānya tām samāveśāt tādātmyena anupraveśāt gavā ādi svabhāva tvāt iti yāvat
translated: For the Sāṃkhya who advocates non-difference, because of the inclusion of the general in the differences such as cows, because of the penetration into them as identical, because of being of the nature of cows and so on, to that extent.

original: bhedasvabhāvatvaṃ sāmānyānām iṣṭam eveti ced ity āha tadātmabhūtānāṃ ceti /
analyzed: bheda svabhāva tvam sāmānyānām iṣṭam eva iti ced iti āha tad ātma bhūtānām ca iti
translated: If it is accepted that the universals have the nature of differences, he says: And if they are of the nature of that...

analyzed: gavādi svabhāvānām sāmānyānām
translated: Of the universals which are of the nature of cows and so on.

analyzed: gavāt iva
translated: Like cows and so on...
Like the universal of being, because of being form and so on.

original: tataś ca viśeṣa eva codyate tad evāha tam evetyādi /
analyzed: tatas ca viśeṣaḥ eva codyate tat eva āha tam eva ityādi
translated: And therefore only the particular is being objected to. He says that very thing with that very... and so on.

original: tam eva cānanyasādhāraṇaṃ bhāvam ayam arthakriyārthī puruṣo bhedābhedaprakāraiḥ paryanuyuṃkute /
analyzed: tam eva ca an anya sādhāraṇam bhāvam ayam arthakriyā arthī puruṣaḥ bheda abheda prakāraiḥ
translated: And this person who seeks to accomplish a purpose questions that very thing which is not common to anything else, in terms of difference and non-difference.

original: anyāpohavādinā 'pi vyāvṛttilakṣaṇo dravyatvādyabhedaḥ svalakṣaṇād iṣṭas tato 'tyantabhedo viśeṣāṇāṃ viruddha ///
analyzed: anya apoha vādinā pi vyāvṛtti lakṣaṇaḥ dravya tva ādi abhedaḥ sva lakṣaṇāt iṣṭaḥ tyanta bhedaḥ viśeṣāṇām
translated: Even by one who advocates the exclusion of other, the non-difference of substance and so on characterized by exclusion is accepted from the specific characteristic, therefore the absolute difference of the particulars is contradictory...🔽...

original: vyatvādyabhedo 'sya / / syābādhaka eva tasya kalpitatvāt tasmāt pāramārthiko
analyzed: sya sya ābādhakaḥ eva tasya kalpita tvāt tasmāt pāramārthikaḥ
translated: The non-difference of the universal etc. is not contradicted, because it is imagined. Therefore, the real difference

original: bhedaḥ svalakṣaṇānām upakalpitam ekatvam anena ca prakāreṇa bhedābhedāv iṣṭāv asmābhis
analyzed: bhedaḥ sva lakṣaṇānām upakalpitam eka tvam anena ca prakāreṇa bheda abhedau iṣṭau asmābhiḥ
translated: of the individual characteristics is imagined as oneness by this method. And in this way, we accept both difference and non-difference.

analyzed: tat eva darśayan āha
translated: To show just that, he says:

analyzed: sarvatra ityādi
translated: In every case... etc.

analyzed: sāmānyasya ca vyāvṛtti lakṣaṇasya abhyupagamāt iti saṃbandhaḥ
translated: And because the universal, which is characterized by exclusion, is accepted, this is the connection.

original: na vyāvṛttirūpeṇa sāmānye ///🔽uktam iti sāmānyād avyatirekād bhedānām aikyaṃ bhedavad eva vā /
analyzed: na vyāvṛtti rūpeṇa sāmānye    iti
translated: Not in the form of exclusion, in the universal...🔽It is said... etc. Because of the non-difference from the universal, either the oneness of the differences is like the difference,

original: sāmānyasyāpy anekatvam ity uktaṃ prāṅ na sāmānyam aṅgīkṛtya bhedānām aikyam ucyate /
analyzed: sāmānyasya api aneka tvam iti uktam prāk na sāmānyam aṅgīkṛtya bhedānām aikyam ucyate
translated: or the multiplicity of the universal is said before. The oneness of the differences is not said by accepting the universal.

original: kiṃtu yo 'sau viśeṣas tenaivābheda ity āha /
analyzed: kiṃtu yaḥ sau viśeṣaḥ tena eva abhedaḥ iti āha
translated: But the non-difference is just by that particularity. He says:

analyzed: sva ātmanā eva ityādi
translated: By its own nature... etc.

original: svenaiva viśeṣarūpeṇa gavāśvādīnām abhede tad / / / dravyaṃ ni ///
analyzed: svena eva viśeṣa rūpeṇa gavāśva ādīnām abhede tat dravyam ni
translated: In the non-difference of cows, horses, etc. by their own particular form, that... is determined as a substance.

original: vaḥ / dvayor iti gavi cāśve ca /
analyzed: vaḥ dvayoḥ iti gavi ca aśve ca
translated: Of two... means of the cow and the horse.

original: yasmād eko 'pi hi kāraṇatvenābhimato gopadārthaḥ tatāṃ arthakriyāṃ vāhaodhasvabhāvāṃ tatsvabhāvatvāt /
analyzed: yasmāt ekaḥ api hi kāraṇa tvena abhimataḥ go padārthaḥ arthakriyām tad svabhāva tvāt
translated: Because even one thing, which is accepted as the cause, the meaning of the word cow, performs that function, which is of the nature of carrying, because it has that nature.

analyzed: tad artha kriyā karaṇa svabhāva tvāt eva karoti
translated: Because it has the nature of performing that function, it does.

original: tadanyasyāpi tasmād godravyād anyasyāpi aśvasya tad vāhadoha / / / / ra / / / / ///
analyzed: tad anyasya api tasmāt go dravyāt anyasya api aśvasya tat
translated: Of that other also, of a horse, which is other than that cow-substance, that function of carrying and milking, etc.
Commentary on the Pramana-vartika🔽V. T. S. V.

original: v / t / s / v / / / sya bheda / / / / / / na ahrīkā nagnatayā /
analyzed: r na ahrīkā nagna tayā
translated: The difference of that from that is not due to the absence of shame, like nakedness.

original: nirlajjaḥ kṣapalakāḥ ayuktābhidhānasya kusmitatvāt kim apīty āha /
analyzed: nirlajjaḥ kṣapalakāḥ ayukta abhidhānasya kusmita tvāt kim api iti āha
translated: The shameless are the impious, because improper speech is a kind of laughter. To show that it is something, he says:

analyzed: aślīlam grāmyam
translated: Indecent means vulgar.

original: sarvaḥ sarvasvabhāvo na ca sarvasvabhāva iti yat pralapanti pratikṣiptaṃ tad api /
analyzed: sarvaḥ sarva svabhāvaḥ na ca sarva svabhāvaḥ iti yat pralapanti pratikṣiptam tat api
translated: And what they prattle - that all has every nature and also does not have every nature - that is also rejected.

original: kasmād ekāntasaṃbhāvād ekasyaivāntasyātyantabhedaprakārasya saṃbhavāt syād uṣṭro dadhisvalakṣaṇasyaikyāt syān na dadhi avasthābhedād aślīlam
analyzed: kasmāt ekānta saṃbhāvāt ekasya eva antasya atyanta bheda prakārasya saṃbhavāt syāt uṣṭraḥ dadhi sva lakṣaṇasya aikyāt syāt na dadhi avasthā bhedāt aślīlam
translated: Why? Because of the possibility of one extreme, of the possibility of only one extreme kind of complete difference. It could be a camel, because of the identity of the individual characteristic of curd. It could not be curd, because of the difference in state. Indecent

analyzed: iti asya vyākhyānam ayuktam
translated: The explanation of this is improper.

analyzed: aślīlam iti asya grāmya paryāya tvāt  aheya upādeyam iti
translated: Because indecent is a synonym for vulgar.🔽What is to be neither rejected nor accepted.

analyzed: a tyājyām a grāhyam ca
translated: What is not to be abandoned and not to be grasped.

analyzed: kasmāt a pariniṣṭhānāt
translated: Why? Because of non-finality.

original: yadi hi kiṃcit sukhasādhana / / / / /iścitam anyac ca duḥ / / / ///
analyzed: yadi hi kiṃcid sukha sādhana anyat ca duḥ
translated: If something is desired as a means of happiness and something else as a means of suffering,

analyzed: R svabhāva tvāt na ca sarva svabhāva tvāt
translated: Because of being of its own nature, and not because of being of the nature of everything.

analyzed: atas ca ākulam ekasya antasya grahītum aśakya tvāt
translated: And therefore it is confused, because it is impossible to grasp one extreme.

original: tadanvaye vā tasya svabhāvabhedasya paraparam anvaye vā sarvasyobhayarūpatvaṃ ubhayagrahaṇam anekatvopalakṣaṇaṃ tasmin sati /
analyzed: tad anvaye vā tasya svabhāva bhedasya para param anvaye vā sarvasya ubhaya rūpa tvam ubhaya grahaṇam aneka tva upalakṣaṇam tasmin sati
translated: Or in the continuation of that, in the continuation of that distinction of its own nature, in the continuation of that, everything has both forms. The grasping of both is a mark of multiplicity. When that exists,

original: tadviśeṣasya uṣṭra uṣṭra eva na dadhi /
analyzed: tad viśeṣasya uṣṭraḥ uṣṭraḥ eva na dadhi
translated: the distinction of that, the camel is only a camel, not curd.

original: dadhi dadhy eva noṣṭra ity evaṃlakṣaṇasya nirākṛteḥ dadhi khādety e / / ///
analyzed: dadhi dadhi eva na uṣṭraḥ iti evaṃlakṣaṇasya nirākṛteḥ dadhi khāda iti
translated: Curd is only curd, not a camel. Because of the exclusion of that kind, curd is eaten.

analyzed: syāt
translated: By the word 'curd', curd would be.

original: nāpi sa evoṣṭra evoṣṭra ity ekāntavādaḥ /
analyzed: na api saḥ eva uṣṭraḥ eva uṣṭraḥ iti ekānta vādaḥ
translated: Nor is it the case that it is only a camel, the extreme view.

original: yenānyo 'pi dadhyādikaḥ syād uṣṭraḥ tathā dadhy api syād uṣṭraḥ nāpi tad eva dadhy eva yenānyad apy uṣṭrādikaṃ syād dadhi etena sarvasyobhayarūpatvaṃ
analyzed: yena anyaḥ api dadhi ādikaḥ syāt uṣṭraḥ tathā dadhi api syāt uṣṭraḥ na api tat eva dadhi eva yena anyat api uṣṭra ādikam syāt dadhi etena sarvasya ubhaya rūpa tvam
translated: By which another also would be a camel, such as curd, and curd would also be a camel. Nor is it that it is only curd, by which another also, such as a camel, would be curd. By this, the having of both forms by everything

analyzed: vyākhyātam
translated: is explained.

original: tadviśeṣanirākṛter ity etat tad anayor ityādinā vyācaṣṭe /🔽ubhayathā hi da /u / / / / / / viśeṣaḥ syā ///
analyzed: tad viśeṣa nirākṛteḥ iti etat tat anayoḥ ityādinā vyācaṣṭe  ubhayathā hi daḥ u viśeṣaḥ syā
translated: This 'because of the exclusion of that distinction' is explained by 'that of these two' and so on.

analyzed: uṣṭra sva rūpe eva niyatam syāt
translated: For in both ways, there would be a distinction of that, it would be determined only in the form of a camel.

analyzed: evam dadhnaḥ api vācyam
translated: The same should be said about curd.

original: ādyasya tāvad asaṃbhavas tad ityādinā kathyate tad evam anayor dadhyuṣṭrayor na kaścid viśeṣa iti saṃbandhaḥ /
analyzed: ādyasya tāvat asaṃbhavaḥ tat ityādinā kathyate tat evam anayoḥ dadhi uṣṭrayoḥ na kaścid viśeṣaḥ iti saṃbandhaḥ
translated: The impossibility of the first is stated by that and so on. Thus, there is no difference between these two, curd and camel, this is the connection.

original: ekasyāpīty dadhna uṣṭrasya vā kasyacit tadrūpābhāvasya uṣṭrarūpābhāvasya dadhirūpabhāvasya cābhāvāt /
analyzed: ekasya api iti dadhnaḥ uṣṭrasya vā kasyacid tad rūpa abhāvasya uṣṭra rūpa abhāvasya dadhi rūpa bhāvasya ca abhāvāt
translated: Of even one, either curd or camel, because of the absence of that form, the absence of the form of a camel, and the absence of the existence of the form of curd.

analyzed: dvitīyasya api prakārasya abhāvam āha svarūpasya ityādi
translated: He states the absence of the second type by of its own nature and so on.

analyzed: ad-
yatasya uṣṭra svabhāva niyatasya dadhi svabhāva niyatasya ca abhāvāt
translated: Because of the absence of the nature of a camel, which is determined by the nature of a camel, and of the nature of curd, which is determined by the nature of curd.

original: athāsti dadhyuṣṭrayor atiśayaḥ kaścid yenātiśayena dadhi khādeti coditaḥ puruṣo bhedena vartate /
analyzed: atha asti dadhi uṣṭrayoḥ atiśayaḥ kaścid yena atiśayena dadhi khāda iti coditaḥ puruṣaḥ bhedena vartate
translated: Now, if there is some superiority of curd and camel, by which superiority, when prompted to eat curd, the person acts differently.

analyzed: uṣṭra parihāreṇa dadhi eva pravartate
translated: He proceeds with curd, avoiding the camel.

original: sa evātiśāyo dadhi sa cānyatroṣṭro nāsti anubhayaṃ vibhaktasvarūpaṃ sarvaṃ vastu / / / / / / paramārthaḥ ekatvaṃ tu ///
analyzed: saḥ eva atiśāyaḥ dadhi sa ca anyatra uṣṭraḥ na asti anubhayam vibhakta svarūpam sarvam vastu paramārthaḥ ekatvam tu
translated: That very superiority is curd, and that does not exist elsewhere in the camel. All things with a distinct nature are not both. The ultimate truth is oneness. But...

original: vyākhye / / / iti dadhikṣīrayoḥ tathā codita iti dadhi khādeti coditaḥ puruṣo bhedena vartate /
translated: It should be explained thus: The person enjoined by 'Eat curd' exists separately from the curd.

analyzed: uṣṭra parihāreṇa dadhi eva pravartate
translated: He engages in curd alone, avoiding the camel.

original: sa evātiśayo dadhi sa sānyatroṣṭre nāstīti anubhayaṃ vibhaktasvarūpaṃ sarvaṃ vastu tad eva paramārthaḥ ekatvaṃ tu kalpitaṃ /
analyzed: saḥ eva atiśayaḥ dadhi sa sa anyatra uṣṭre na asti iti anubhayam vibhakta svarūpam sarvam vastu tat eva paramārthaḥ eka tvam tu kalpitam
translated: That very excellence, curd, does not exist elsewhere than in the camel. Thus, all things, whose distinct nature is not both, are that very ultimate reality. But oneness is imagined.

analyzed: dadhnā eva aparam uṣṭra ādikam anubhava rūpam vyākhyeyam
translated: It should be explained that the other, such as the camel, is of the nature of experience only of curd.

analyzed: coditaḥ iti dadhi khāda iti coditaḥ
translated: The person enjoined by 'Eat curd' exists separately from the curd.

analyzed: kṣīra vikāraḥ dadhi na anyatra iti uṣṭre
translated: Curd is a modification of milk, not elsewhere, i.e., in the camel.

original: sa evātiśayo dadhi kiṃbhūta arthakriyārthipravṛttiviṣayaḥ dadhisādhyārthakriyā / / tayā yo 'rthī puruṣas tasya pravṛttiviṣayaḥ kiṃ kāraṇaṃ tatphaletyādi
analyzed: saḥ eva atiśayaḥ dadhi kiṃbhūta arthakriyā arthi pravṛtti viṣayaḥ dadhi sādhya arthakriyā tayā yaḥ rthī puruṣaḥ tasya pravṛtti viṣayaḥ kim kāraṇam tad phala ityādi
translated: That very excellence, curd, is what? The object of engagement for one who desires the result, i.e., the result accomplished by curd. The person who desires that result is the object of engagement. What is the reason? The result, etc.

original: dadhnaiva sādhyatvāt phalaviśeṣaḥ saivāsau viśeṣaś ceti vigrahaḥ /
analyzed: dadhnā eva sādhya tvāt phala viśeṣaḥ sā eva asau viśeṣaḥ ca iti vigrahaḥ
translated: Because curd alone is to be accomplished, it is a particular result. That very distinction is what is to be analyzed.

original: tasyopādānabhāvo hetubhāvas tena lakṣitaḥ svabhāvo yasya vastunas tad e / / / / /i /i ///
analyzed: tasya upādāna bhāvaḥ hetu bhāvaḥ tena lakṣitaḥ svabhāvaḥ yasya vastunaḥ tat
translated: The state of being its material cause, the state of being its cause, is characterized by that. The nature of that thing is what is to be analyzed.
The nature of curd.

analyzed: anyatra iti uṣṭre
translated: In other cases means in a camel.

analyzed: kasmāt  dadhi arthinaḥ tatra uṣṭre pravṛti abhāvāt
translated: Why?🔽Because one seeking curd does not engage in activity towards a camel.

analyzed: bhinnau niyata arthau
translated: The two are different and have a fixed meaning.

analyzed: dhī dhvanī jñānam śabdaḥ ca
translated: The cognition and the word.

analyzed: tad abhāvāt bhinna buddhi śabda bhāvāt  bhedānām saṃhāra vādasya
translated: Because of the absence of that, i.e. because of the absence of a different cognition and word.🔽Of the doctrine of the unity of differences.

analyzed: ekīkaraṇa vādasya asaṃbhavaḥ
translated: The impossibility of the doctrine of unification.

original: bhedena gṛhītayoḥ śrutayor vā ekatvenopasaṃharo nirdeśaḥ syād uṣṭro dadhītyādi /
analyzed: bhedena gṛhītayoḥ śrutayoḥ vā eka tvena upasaṃharaḥ nirdeśaḥ syāt uṣṭraḥ dadhi ityādi
translated: The instruction would be the unification of what is grasped or heard as different into one, such as the camel is curd and so on.

analyzed: saḥ yam ityādinā vyācaṣṭe
translated: He explains this with this is that and so on.🔽Where?

original: kva ///🔽m ākāram apaśyan kathaṃ buddhyādhimucyetārthān iti saṃbandhaḥ /
analyzed: kva  ākāram apaśyān katham buddhyā adhimucyeta arthān iti saṃbandhaḥ
translated: ...🔽Not seeing the form, how could one be convinced by cognition of the objects? This is the connection.

analyzed: kim viśiṣṭayā buddhyā iti āha asaṃsṛṣṭa ityādi
translated: What kind of special cognition? He says unmixed and so on.

analyzed: raḥ yasmin arthe saḥ tathā uktaḥ
translated: That in which the object is, it is said to be so.

original: sa yasyā buddher asti sā asaṃsṛṣṭānyākāravatī vibhaktārthagrāhiṇyeti yāvat /
analyzed: sa yasyāḥ buddheḥ asti sā asaṃsṛṣṭā anya ākāravatī vibhaktā artha grāhiṇyā iti yāvat
translated: That which has such a cognition is unmixed, having a different form, grasping a differentiated object - this is the extent.

original: abhilaped vā kathaṃ pratiniyatasaṃketena dhvaninety ākūtaṃ /
analyzed: abhilapet vā katham pratiniyata saṃketena dhvaninā iti ākūtam
translated: Or how could one express it with a word having a fixed convention? This is the intention.

analyzed: kasmāt na adhimucyeta iti āha
translated: Why are they not convinced? He says:

analyzed: vibhāga abhāvāt bhāvānām iti tat saṃhāra vādaḥ iti
translated: Because of the absence of differentiation of things, this is the doctrine of their unification.

original: bhedasaṃhāravādo na syāt syād uṣṭra ityādikaḥ /🔽atha punar asaṃsṛṣṭau dadhyuṣṭrau pratipadya saṃh / ///

translated: Because the cause of destruction is not present, something might not be destroyed at all.

analyzed: kasmāt vaikalya ityādi sahakāri sannidhāna vaikalyam
translated: Why? Because of the incompleteness, etc. The incompleteness of the presence of cooperating factors.

analyzed: viprakṛṣṭa viṣayasya svabhāvasya abhāve sādhye svabhāva anupalambhaḥ eva apramāṇ
translated: When the nature of a remote object is to be established as absent, the non-apprehension of nature itself is not a means of valid knowledge.

original: palambha eva niścetum aśakyaḥ /🔽svabhāvādivirakarṣiṇāṃ kenacit saha kāryakāraṇabhāvasyaivāniścayāt satyam etat kiṃtu sanuddiṣṭaviṣayasyābhāvamātrasya praptipattau śakyate
analyzed: eva niścetum    svabhāva ādi virakarṣiṇām kenacid saha kārya kāraṇa bhāvasya eva aniścayāt satyam etat kiṃtu san uddiṣṭa viṣayasya abhāva mātrasya śakyate
translated: It is impossible to ascertain the apprehension itself.🔽Because the relation of cause and effect with something remote in terms of nature, etc. is not ascertained at all. This is true, but when the mere absence of an object that is not specified is to be established,

original: etāvad vaktuṃ kāraṇam antareṇa kāryaṃ svabhāvādiviprakṣṛṭam apy avaśyaṃ na bhavatīti /
analyzed: etāvat vaktum kāraṇam antareṇa kāryam svabhāva ādi viprakṣṛṭam api avaśyam na bhavati iti
translated: it is possible to say this much: Without a cause, an effect, even if remote in terms of nature, etc., cannot possibly exist.

analyzed: iyatā leśena asya upanyāsaḥ  atas eva sā
translated: This much is stated in brief.

analyzed: R na uddiṣṭa viṣayaḥ pi śakyate vyavasthāpayitum
translated: For this very reason, it is possible to establish even an unspecified object.

analyzed: nanu ityādi paraḥ
translated: The opponent says But...

original: agner vināśe 'pi vāsagṛhādau dhūmasya darśanāt tathā cāsaty api kāraṇe kāryaṃ dṛṣṭam iti vyabhicāraḥ /
analyzed: agneḥ vināśe vāsagṛha ādau dhūmasya darśanāt tathā ca asati api kāraṇe kāryam dṛṣṭam iti vyabhicāraḥ
translated: Even when the fire is destroyed, smoke is seen in a house, etc. Thus, an effect is seen even when the cause does not exist, so there is a fallacy.

original: asati kāraṇe kāryaṃ na syād ity anena vākyena kāraṇasthitikālabhāvikāryaṃ /
analyzed: asati kāraṇe kāryam na syāt iti anena vākyena kāraṇa sthiti kāla bhāvi kāryam
translated: By this sentence [that you have quoted], [the opponent means to say that] the effect exists at the time when the cause exists.

original: yāvat kāraṇasattā tāvat kāryasattety arthaḥ /🔽evaṃ na brūmo yena kā ///
analyzed: yāvat kāraṇa sattā tāvat kārya sattā iti arthaḥ  evam na brūmaḥ yena kā
translated: The meaning is: as long as the cause exists, the effect exists.

analyzed: saṃgaḥ syāt
translated: We do not say this, by which there would be a contradiction.

original: kāraṇāt sakṛdutpannasya kāryasya kāraṇanāśe 'pi kālāntaram avsthānāt /
analyzed: kāraṇāt sakṛt utpannasya kāryasya kāraṇa nāśe pi kāla antaram
translated: [The opponent says:] Because the effect, once produced from the cause, remains for some time even after the destruction of the cause.

original: kiṃ tarhy anena vākyenocyata ity āha heturahitetyādi /
analyzed: kim tarhi anena vākyena ucyate iti āha hetu rahita ityādi
translated: Then what is meant by this sentence? He says: When the cause is destroyed...

original: yady apy ayaṃ granthena ca tathetyādi granthena vyavahitaḥ tathāpy artha / / ///
analyzed: yadi api ayam granthena ca tathā ityādi granthena vyavahitaḥ tathā api
translated: Although this [sentence] is separated by the text beginning with tatha [in the opponent's quotation], still the meaning...

original: ḥ kāraṇe naṣṭe kāryasya sthānam eva nāstīti kuto vyabhicārāśaṃkā /
analyzed: kāraṇe naṣṭe kāryasya sthānam eva na asti iti kutas vyabhicāra āśaṅkā
translated: ... is that when the cause is destroyed, the effect has no existence at all. So how can there be any doubt of a contradiction?

original: tathā hi yo 'gnijanyo dhūmakṣaṇas tasyāgnau vinaṣṭe nāstyavasthānaṃ /
analyzed: tathā hi yaḥ gni janyaḥ dhūma kṣaṇaḥ tasya agnau vinaṣṭe na asti avasthānam
translated: For example, the moment of smoke produced by fire, when that fire is destroyed, has no duration.

original: yato yasmin kṣaṇe dvitīye agnijanyasya dhūmakṣaṇasya sattā tasminn eva kāraṇabhūto 'gnikṣaṇo vinaṣṭas tadanantaraṃ ca tṛtīye kṣaṇe dhūmakṣaṇo
analyzed: yatas yasmin kṣaṇe dvitīye agni janyasya dhūma kṣaṇasya sattā tasmin eva kāraṇa bhūtaḥ gni kṣaṇaḥ vinaṣṭaḥ tad anantaram ca tṛtīye kṣaṇe dhūma kṣaṇaḥ
translated: Because in the second moment, when the moment of smoke produced by fire exists, in that very moment the cause, the moment of fire, is destroyed, and immediately after that, in the third moment, the moment of smoke is also destroyed.🔽So how can there be...

analyzed: vinaṣṭaḥ iti ku
translated: and the object has ceased to exist, how can there be a cognition of it?

original: gnihetukas tad eva darśayann āha na ca tathetyādi /
analyzed: eva darśayan āha na ca
translated: Showing just that, he says And it is not like that and so on.

original: tathā sthāyīti naṣṭe 'py ādye kāraṇe kālāntarasthāyī tadupādānaḥ pūrvaniruddhahetūpādānaḥ kathaṃ tarhi pascāt yo 'pi dhūmo 'gnihetuka ity ucyata
analyzed: tathā sthāyī iti naṣṭe pi ādye kāraṇe kāla antara sthāyī tad upādānaḥ pūrva niruddha hetu upādānaḥ katham tarhi pascāt dhūmaḥ gni hetukaḥ iti ucyata
translated: Thus, the permanent - even when the first cause has ceased, how can the permanent one that exists for some time later, which has that as its material cause, which has the previously ceased cause as its material cause, be said to be caused by fire?

analyzed: iti āha
translated: Thus, he says:

analyzed: pāraṃparya ityādi
translated: By a series of causes and so on.

original: ādyaṃ tāvad dhūmakṣaṇaṃ vahnir eva janayati sa dhūmakṣaṇo 'paraṃ so 'py apara / / ///
analyzed: ādyam tāvat dhūma kṣaṇam vahniḥ eva janayati sa dhūma kṣaṇaḥ param
translated: First, the first moment of smoke is produced by fire itself. That moment of smoke produces another, and that another, and so on.
Because of the production of that,
it is designated as its effect.

original: tasyādyasya kāraṇasya paścātyam api kāryam ity evaṃ vyapadeśaḥ /🔽yady asya hetoḥ kathaṃcit pramāṇenābhāvaḥ sidhyet tadā tatphalaṃ tasya pratiṣedhyamānasya hetoḥ phalaṃ nāstīti niściyate /
analyzed: tasya ādyasya kāraṇasya paścātyam api kāryam iti evam vyapadeśaḥ  yadi asya hetoḥ kathaṃcid pramāṇena abhāvaḥ sidhyet tadā tad phalam tasya pratiṣedhyamānasya hetoḥ phalam na asti iti niściyate
translated: The later one is also the effect of that first cause. Thus it is designated.🔽If the non-existence of this cause were somehow established by a means of knowledge, then it would be ascertained that the effect of that which is being negated, the effect of that negated cause, does not exist.

original: tadabhāvaḥ pratīyeta hetunā yadi kenacid ity asyaiva vakṣyamānasya / / ///
analyzed: tad abhāvaḥ pratīyeta hetunā yadi kenacid iti asya eva vakṣyamānasya
translated: That non-existence would be known by some means - this will be explained later.
But when the object is not specified, it is not required in this way.

original: yadi kāraṇaṃ na bhavet kāryam apy avaśyaṃ na bhaved dheturahitāyā bhāvotpatter asaṃbhāvād ity etāvanmātrasya pratipādanāt tac cānantaraṃ evoktam
analyzed: yadi kāraṇam na bhavet kāryam api avaśyam na bhavet hetu rahitāyāḥ bhāva utpatteḥ asaṃbhāvāt iti etāvat mātrasya pratipādanāt tat ca anantaram eva uktam
translated: If the cause were not to exist, the effect would certainly not exist, because the origination of an existent thing without a cause is impossible. This much alone is being taught, and that was just stated:

analyzed: iti svabhāva ityādi
translated: Thus, the nature... etc.

original: arthasyeti vyāpakasya svabhāve liṅginy asatvena sādhye svabhāvānupalambhaś ca vyāpakānupalambha ///
analyzed: arthasya iti vyāpakasya svabhāve liṅgini asatvena sādhye svabhāva anupalambhaḥ ca vyāpaka anupalambha
translated: When the nature of the pervaded is being proven by the non-existence of the pervader, the non-apprehension of the nature is the non-apprehension of the pervader.

analyzed: svabhāvaḥ eva ityādinā vyācaṣṭe
translated: He explains with The nature itself... etc.

analyzed: kiṃcid iti vyāpaka anupalambhaḥ
translated: Something refers to the non-apprehension of the pervader.

original: yadi anupalabhyamāno vyāpakaḥ svabhāvo 'sya niṣedhyābhimatasya vyāpyasya siddhaḥ syāt tadā bhavet pramāṇaṃ yathā vṛkṣatvaṃ vyāpakaṃ si / /
analyzed: yadi anupalabhyamānaḥ vyāpakaḥ svabhāvaḥ niṣedhya abhimatasya vyāpyasya siddhaḥ syāt tadā bhavet pramāṇam yathā vṛkṣa tvam vyāpakam
translated: If the pervading nature, which is not being apprehended, were established as the pervaded that is the object of negation, then it would be a valid means of knowledge, just as the pervading tree is established by some means of knowledge called the non-apprehension of the nature.

analyzed: pramāṇavārttikaṭīkā
translated: Commentary on the Pramana-vartika

original: vaḥ pratīyeta hetunā kenacit svabhāvānupalaṃbhākhyena yadītyādinārtham āha yady asya kārakasyābhāvaḥ sidhyed iti saṃbandhaḥ /
analyzed: R vaḥ pratīyeta hetunā kenacid svabhāva anupalambha ākhyena yadi ityādinā artham āha yadi asya   abhāvaḥ sidhyet iti sambandhaḥ
translated: By what means of knowledge could the absence of the cause be known? He states the meaning with If... etc. The connection is: if the absence of that cause were to be established.

original: vyāpakasya ca svabhāvasyābhāvaḥ kutaścid gamakād dhetor iti upalabdhilakṣaṇaprāptānupalambhāt sa eva hi pratiṣedhe ga / / / / / / / / / / / / / /
analyzed: vyāpakasya ca svabhāvasya abhāvaḥ kutaścid gamakāt hetoḥ iti upalabdhi lakṣaṇa prāpta anupalambhāt saḥ eva hi pratiṣedhe
translated: And the non-existence of an all-pervading nature is from a reason that indicates something. Thus, from the non-apprehension of what is perceptible, that itself is the means of knowing in the case of negation.

original: ddh / kārakavyāpakayor abhāvāsiddhau nivartye 'pi kārye vyāpye ca saṃśayāt /
analyzed: kāraka vyāpakayoḥ abhāva asiddhau nivartye kārye vyāpye ca saṃśayāt
translated: When the non-existence of the effect and the pervaded is not established, there is doubt even in the case of the negated effect and the pervaded.

original: etac coddiṣṭaviṣayasyābhāvasya sādhane draṣṭavyaṃ yathoktaṃ prāk /
analyzed: etat ca uddiṣṭa viṣayasya abhāvasya sādhane draṣṭavyam yathā uktam prāk
translated: And this should be seen in the proof of the non-existence of the specified object, as stated earlier.

original: yadi svabhāvābhāve sādhye tadanupalambha evāpramāṇām ucyate katham idānīṃ bhāvasya ghaṭādeḥ svayam anupalabdher abhāvasiddhiḥ /
analyzed: yadi svabhāva abhāve sādhye tad anupalambhaḥ eva apramāṇām ucyate katham idānīm bhāvasya ghaṭa ādeḥ svayam anupalabdheḥ abhāva siddhiḥ
translated: If, in the case of proving the non-existence of nature, only the non-apprehension of that is said to be a non-means of knowledge, then how is the establishment of the non-existence of an existent thing like a pot through its own non-apprehension?

analyzed: uttaram āha
translated: The answer is: of the visible...

analyzed: in margin line
translated: in the margin...

analyzed: na svabhāva a viprakarṣam āha
translated: he does not say due to the absence of nature or due to remoteness.

original: tasyaivaṃvidhasya bhāvasyānupalabdhasya sataḥ bhāvābhāvaḥ sattāyā abhāvaḥ pratītyate /
analyzed: tasya evaṃvidhasya bhāvasya anupalabdhasya sataḥ bhāva abhāvaḥ sattāyāḥ abhāvaḥ pratītyate
translated: The non-existence of the existence of such an existent thing, which is non-apprehended, is the non-existence of existence.

original: kadā darśanābhāvakāraṇāsaṃbhave sati darśanābhāvasya kāranaṃ kāraṇāntarāṇāṃ
analyzed: kadā darśana abhāva kāraṇa asaṃbhave sati darśana abhāvasya kāranam kāraṇa antarāṇām
translated: When? When the causes of the absence of seeing do not exist. The cause of the absence of seeing is the other causes.
When it is not possible, the meaning is: when the other conditions of perception are complete.

analyzed: bhāvaḥ hi ityādinā vyācaṣṭe
translated: He explains with For an existent... etc.

analyzed: ātmānam bhāvayati bodhayati iti bhāvaḥ
translated: It causes itself to exist, it causes itself to be known, therefore it is an existent.

analyzed: svabhāva ādi aviprakṛṣṭaḥ svabhāva viśeṣaḥ
translated: The specific nature is not removed from the nature.

original: sa yadi bhaved yathāsvaṃ grāhakeṇa kāraṇena yasya yad grāhakam indriyaṃ tenopalabhya eva bhavet etena dṛśyasyety etad vyākhyātaṃ sa yathokto
analyzed: sa yadi bhavet yathāsvam grāhakeṇa kāraṇena yasya yat grāhakam indriyam tena upalabhyaḥ eva bhavet etena dṛśyasya iti etat vyākhyātam sa yathā uktaḥ
translated: If it exists, it would be perceived by its own apprehending cause, by whatever apprehending faculty it has, by that it would be perceived. This explains the word visible.

original: ṣu vyavadhānādiṣv ādiśabdād vaikalyapratibandhādiṣu asatsūpalambhapratyayeṣu satsv iti yāvat /
analyzed: vyavadhāna ādiṣu ādi śabdāt vaikalya pratibandha ādiṣu asatsu upalambha pratyayeṣu satsu iti yāvat
translated: In the case of those, in the case of obstructions etc., the word etc. refers to deficiencies, hindrances, etc., when the conditions of perception are present, as far as they are present.

original: upalabhyata eva nānyathā /🔽tathābhūto 'nupalabdhas tv asann iti niścīyate kiṃ kāraṇaṃ tādṛśaḥ sataḥ upalabdhilakṣaṇaprāptasya sataḥ /
analyzed: upalabhyate eva na anyathā  tathābhūtaḥ nupalabdhaḥ tu asan iti niścīyate kim kāraṇam tādṛśaḥ sataḥ upalabdhi lakṣaṇa prāptasya sataḥ
translated: It is perceived, not otherwise.🔽But when it is not perceived in that way, it is ascertained to be non-existent. What is the reason? Because of the non-deviation of perception of that which exists, of that which exists as having the nature of being perceptible.

original: upalambhāvyabhicārāt ya evāyaṃ svabhāvasyābhāvaṃ niścaye dṛśyasya darśanetyādinokto 'yam eva hetur ve ///
analyzed: upalambha avyabhicārāt yaḥ eva ayam svabhāvasya abhāvam niścaye dṛśyasya darśana ityādinā uktaḥ yam eva hetuḥ
translated: This very reason, which was stated earlier with For the non-perception of that which has the nature of being perceptible, if it were to be seen... etc., is the same reason here.

original: dhye viruddhasya cetyādi caśabdo bhinnakramaḥ tadviruddhopalabdhau ceti🔽draṣṭavyaḥ yasyābhāvaḥ sādhyas tena yo viruddhas tena yo viruddhas tasyopalabdhau
analyzed: ca iti  draṣṭavyaḥ yasya abhāvaḥ sādhyaḥ tena yaḥ viruddhaḥ tena yaḥ viruddhaḥ tasya upalabdhau
translated: The word ca (and) in and the perception of what is contrary to it should be read in a different sequence.🔽When there is the perception of what is contrary to that of which the absence is to be proved,

original: ca syād asattāyāḥ pratiṣedhyābhāvasya niścayaḥ kiṃ kāranaṃ viruddhasya bhāvasya bhāve
analyzed: ca syāt asattāyāḥ pratiṣedhya abhāvasya niścayaḥ kim kāranam viruddhasya bhāvasya bhāve
translated: there can be the ascertainment of the non-existence of the object to be negated. What is the reason? Because when the contrary existent is present,

analyzed: sattāyām tad bhāva bādhanāt
translated: the existence of that [object to be negated] is contradicted.

original: tasya niṣedhyābhimatasya sattābādhanāt dravyoḥ sahānavasthānād iti yāvat /🔽yo hītyādinā /🔽vyācaṣṭe /
analyzed: tasya niṣedhya abhimatasya sattā bādhanāt dravyoḥ saha anavasthānāt iti yāvat  yaḥ hi ityādinā  vyācaṣṭe
translated: Because the existence of that which is intended to be negated is contradicted, as two substances cannot coexist.

analyzed: yaḥ hi bhāvaḥ yena
translated: He explains with yo hi bhāvo yena...

original: i / / / / ity āha tadupādānayor ityādi tayor viruddhayor ya upādāne tayor anyonyaṃ parasparaṃ /
analyzed: āha
translated: He says tadupadāyayoḥ etc. The two contraries have their respective bases, i.e., they are mutually dependent.

original: dvaiguṇyaṃ tasyāśrayatvena śītopādānam uṣṇopādānavaiguṇyasyāśraya itarac cetarasyety arthaḥ /
analyzed: dvaiguṇyam tasya āśraya tvena śīta upādānam uṣṇa upādāna vaiguṇyasya āśrayaḥ itarat ca itarasya iti arthaḥ
translated: The basis of the cold cause is the absence of the hot cause, and vice versa. This is the meaning.

original: tena kāraṇena viruddhayoḥ śītoṣṇakāryayor ekatra yugapadārambhavirodhāt /
analyzed: tena kāraṇena viruddhayoḥ śīta uṣṇa kāryayoḥ ekatra yugapad ārambha virodhāt
translated: For that reason, because the simultaneous arising of the two contrary effects, cold and hot, in one place is contradictory,

analyzed: tayoḥ anantara uktena prakāre
translated: by the aforementioned method,

analyzed: v bdhi prabhede
translated: in the classification of the two.

analyzed: na śītaḥ ityādi
translated: For example, Here there is no cold touch of fire.

original: yady apy atrānupalabdhir iti na śrutis tathāpīdaṃ svabhāvaviruddhākhyaṃ liṅgam anupalabdheḥ sakāśān na pṛthag ucyate /
analyzed: yadi api atra anupalabdhiḥ iti na śrutiḥ tathā api idam svabhāva viruddha ākhyam liṅgam anupalabdheḥ sakāśāt na pṛthak ucyate
translated: Although the word non-apprehension is not heard here, this reason called contradictory to nature is not stated separately from non-apprehension.

original: kiṃ kāraṇaṃ tata evānupalambhād virodhagateḥ virodhāc cābhāvasādhanāt viruddho hi kathaṃ niścīyeta /
analyzed: kim kāraṇam tatas eva anupalambhāt virodha gateḥ virodhāt ca abhāva sādhanāt viruddhaḥ hi katham niścīyeta
translated: What is the reason? Because contradiction is understood from that very non-apprehension, and because absence is established from contradiction. For how can a contradictory [reason] be ascertained?

analyzed: yadi tad upalaṃbhe pratiyoginaḥ
translated: If the non-apprehension of the counter-correlate is in the apprehension of that [contradictory reason],

original: palabdher abhāvāsiddher ity arthād viruddhavi / / ne 'nupalabdhir eva prayu / / / / / / /iti /
analyzed: iti
translated: because absence is not established from the non-apprehension, it is understood that the contradictory [reason] is non-apprehension itself.

original: bhavatu nāmaivaṃvidhāyāyā dṛśyaviṣayā anupalabdheḥ sakāśād abhāvagatir ataś ceyaṃ pramāṇaṃ sā punaḥ katham anumānaṃ kiṃtu pramāṇāntaram eveti
analyzed: bhavatu nāma evaṃvidhāyāḥ dṛśya viṣayā anupalabdheḥ sakāśāt abhāva gatiḥ atas ca iyam pramāṇam sā punar katham anumānam kiṃtu pramāṇa antaram eva iti
translated: Let it be that the cognition of absence from such a kind of non-apprehension of the visible object is thus, and therefore this is a means of valid knowledge. But how is it an inference? Rather, it is a separate means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: bhāvaḥ
translated: This is the point.

original: kathaṃ vā na syād ity ācāryaḥ /
analyzed: katham vā na syāt iti ācāryaḥ
translated: Or how could it not be? says the teacher.

analyzed: dṛṣṭānta anapekṣaṇāt iti paraḥ
translated: Because it does not depend on an example, says the opponent.

analyzed: dṛṣṭānta apekṣam hi anumānam anvaya vyatirekava
translated: For inference depends on an example, and is a means of knowledge based on concomitance and non-concomitance.

original: mānaṃ dṛṣṭāntānapekṣatām edva na hītyādinā prāha /
translated: He says that it does not depend on an example in the following way, beginning with Because it does not depend on an example...

original: asyām ity anupalabdhau kiṃ na nirupākhyam ityādi ācāryaḥ dṛṣṭānta evety arthaḥ /
analyzed: asyām iti anupalabdhau kim na nirupākhyam ityādi ācāryaḥ dṛṣṭānte eva iti arthaḥ
translated: In this [verse], what is not a non-entity? The master [Dignāga] means that it is just an example.

analyzed: tat asat ityādi paraḥ
translated: The opponent [Bhāviveka] says that this is not so, and so on.

original: tad vyomakusumādi asad iti kathaṃ kena pramāṇenāvagantavyaṃ yenaivaṃ syāt /
analyzed: tat vyoma kusuma ādi asat iti katham kena pramāṇena avagantavyam yena evam syāt
translated: How should that non-existent, such as a sky-flower, be understood by what means of knowledge, by which it would be so?

original: anupalaabdher liṅgād abhāve sādhye dṛṣṭāntaḥ syād ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: anupalaabdheḥ liṅgāt abhāve sādhye dṛṣṭāntaḥ syāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that in the proof of non-existence, non-apprehension would be the example by the inferential mark.

analyzed: anupalabdheḥ eva liṅgāt vyoma kusumā
translated: The analysis is that the non-existence of a sky-flower, etc. is known by the inferential mark of non-apprehension alone.

original: idyate dṛṣṭānto yasyā asattāsiddher iti vigrahaḥ /
analyzed: idyate dṛṣṭāntaḥ yasyāḥ asattā siddheḥ iti vigrahaḥ
translated: This is the example for the proof of non-existence.

original: athātrāpy aparo dṛṣṭāntas tasyā vyomakusumādyasattāsiddheḥ sadṛṣṭāntatve vānavasthāprasaṃgaḥ /
analyzed: atha atrā api aparaḥ dṛṣṭāntaḥ tasyāḥ vyoma kusuma ādi asattā siddheḥ sa dṛṣṭānta tve vā anavasthā prasaṃgaḥ
translated: If another example is needed here for the proof of the non-existence of a sky-flower, etc., then there would be an infinite regress.

original: tatrāpy aparo dṛṣṭāntas tatrāpy aparo 'pīti kṛtvā /
analyzed: tatra api aparaḥ dṛṣṭāntaḥ tatra api aparaḥ pi iti kṛtvā
translated: Because another example would be needed there, and another there as well.

original: tathā cānavasthāyāṃ satyāṃ ekasyāpi siddhāv apratipattiḥ /🔽sarvatra tasmād anavasthādoṣaparihārārthaṃ nirupākhya ///
analyzed: tathā ca anavasthāyām satyām ekasya api siddhau apratipattiḥ  sarvatra tasmāt anavasthā doṣa parihāra artham nirupākhya
translated: And in that case, if there is an infinite regress, there is no understanding of even one [example].

original: labdhilakṣaṇaprāptasya anupalabdher ityādāv api prayoge dṛṣṭāntānapekṣaṇād ananumānam anupalabdhiḥ /
translated: Therefore, in order to avoid the fault of infinite regress, in the formulation by the non-apprehension of what is perceptible, etc., apprehension is not an inference, because an example is not needed.

analyzed: śṛṇvan api iti ācāryaḥ
translated: The teacher [Dharmakīrti] says even if one hears.

original: sakṛd uktaṃ yathā svabhāvānupalabdhau nābhāvaḥ sādhyate kiṃtu abhāvavyavahāra iti tacchṛṇvann api /
analyzed: sakṛt uktam yathā svabhāva anupalabdhau na abhāvaḥ sādhyate kiṃtu abhāva vyavahāraḥ iti tat śṛṇvan api
translated: Just as in the statement non-existence is not being proven, but the usage of non-existence, even if one hears that,

original: mūrkhasya trīṇi nāmāni devo divyaḥ prajayatir ity ato devānāṃ mūrkhāṇāṃ pri / / ///
analyzed: mūrkhasya trīṇi nāmāni devaḥ divyaḥ prajayatiḥ iti atas devānām mūrkhāṇām pri
translated: the three names of a fool are god, divine, and victorious. Therefore, the usage of non-existence is being proven, showing that it is dear to the gods, fools, and the victorious.

analyzed: eva asat vyavahāram sādhyam darśayan āha
translated: Showing that the usage of non-existence is what is being proven, he says:

analyzed: nimittam hi ityādi
translated: For the cause... and so on.

analyzed: dṛśyasya anupalabdhiḥ upalabhya anupalabdhiḥ
translated: The non-perception of the perceptible is the perception of non-perception.

original: sā nimittaṃ kāraṇaṃ sadvyavahārāṇāṃ sānupalabdhiḥ svasannidhānād ātmanā sannidhānāt /
analyzed: sā nimittam kāraṇam sat vyavahārāṇām sā anupalabdhiḥ sva sannidhānāt ātmanā sannidhānāt
translated: That is the cause, the reason, for the usage of existence. That non-perception is the presence of itself, due to its own presence.

analyzed: sva nimittān svam
translated: From its own cause, its own form of non-perception...
